headline: AI could transform health care, but will it live up to the hype?
context: The U.S. health care system is rife with problems — as many Americans have experienced firsthand. Access to quality care is patchy, and medical costs can leave people with lifelong debt for treatments that don’t always work. Frustration and anger at the system’s failures were a flash point in the presidential election and may have factored in the December murder of UnitedHealthcare’s CEO.

True progress in transforming health care will require solutions across the political, scientific and medical sectors. But new forms of artificial intelligence have the potential to help. Innovators are racing to deploy AI technologies to make health care more effective, equitable and humane.

annotations.paragraph: AI could spot cancer early, design lifesaving drugs, assist doctors in surgery and even peer into people’s futures to predict and prevent disease. The potential to help people live longer, healthier lives is vast. But physicians and researchers must overcome a legion of challenges to harness AI’s potential.
annotations.reason: This paragraph outlines the potential applications and challenges of AI in health care, directly relating to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: How do doctors ensure that AI is accurate, accessible to all patients, free from bias, respectful of patient privacy and not used for nefarious purposes? “Will it work everywhere? Will it work for everyone?” artificial intelligence expert Rama Chellappa asked at a workshop at the Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg Center last August.

annotations.paragraph: We talked with dozens of scientists and physicians about where AI in medicine stands. Again and again, researchers told us that in most medical areas, AI is still in its infancy, or toddlerhood at best. But the field is growing fast. And though AI-enabled medical devices have been in use since the 1990s, the level of interest, investment and technologies has soared in the last few years.

AI is unlikely to replace doctors, though. Instead, in many cases, it would be a tool used alongside human hands, hearts and minds.

annotations.paragraph: The ability to create such complete digital twins doesn’t exist, at least not yet. Today’s digital twins aren’t full-body representations. Some represent a single organ, such as the heart. Those twins may help design customized medical devices, plan complex heart surgeries or understand how sex hormones may affect heart rhythms. Other still experimental twins model the immune or nervous system.

annotations.paragraph: And it may never be possible to exactly replicate a person, says Roozbeh Jafari, an electrical engineer and computer scientist at MIT Lincoln Laboratory in Lexington, Mass. annotations.paragraph: Digital twins would be more than personal data repositories, says Tina Hernandez-Boussard, a medical informatician at Stanford University. annotations.paragraph: That holistic view is important, says Joseph Wu, a cardiologist at Stanford. “The human mind is the major player in our human health,” he says. DNA and stem cell data can’t predict what type of society a person will be born into or which infectious diseases they might be exposed to. A true digital twin would incorporate those factors and change as a person’s circumstances change, Wu says.

annotations.paragraph: Such data are hard to come by for vulnerable populations, including the uninsured and people from marginalized or underserved communities. annotations.paragraph: With so much health data streaming among our digital devices, privacy is another big area for caution, says Uttandaraman Sundararaj, a biomedical engineer at the University of Calgary in Canada. There’s a chance that personal health data could be hacked. It’s important to encrypt the data or otherwise protect it, Sundararaj says.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses privacy concerns related to AI in health care, which is relevant to the potential transformation AI could bring.

annotations.paragraph: He envisions secure AI systems one day weaving together streams of wearable data to perhaps predict when a heart attack or stroke might occur. That analytical power, Sundararaj says, “gives us the ability to actually see in the future.” — Meghan Rosen
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a specific example of how AI could transform health care by predicting medical events.

annotations.paragraph: A retired Navy veteran caught what he thought was a cold from his great-grandson after taking the sniffling toddler to a petting zoo. The little guy bounced back, but GG-Pop kept feeling worse. He ended up in the emergency room with a cough, fever, muscle aches and difficulty breathing. A chest X-ray indicated he had pneumonia.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a narrative setup but lacks direct relevance to AI's role in health care transformation.

annotations.paragraph: An AI used to analyze his blood revealed that he was at risk of developing sepsis, a life-threatening condition in which the immune system overreacts to infection. More than 1.7 million adults in the United States develop sepsis each year, and without prompt treatment, the condition can lead to tissue or organ damage, hospitalization and death. About 350,000 people who develop sepsis while hospitalized die or are sent to hospice care.
annotations.reason: The paragraph illustrates a specific application of AI in diagnosing and managing a critical health condition, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Doctors admitted GG-Pop to the hospital and gave him fluids and antibiotics. As a backup, his physicians also used another AI that sorted through his past and present electronic medical records and warned doctors that, despite treatment, the man was approaching a sepsis danger zone. The team gave him steroids to help calm his immune system. GG-Pop recovered and was soon onto other adventures with his great-grandson.
annotations.reason: The paragraph continues the narrative of AI's role in patient care, showing its practical application in a medical setting.

annotations.paragraph: Some AI-based risk predictors for sepsis are already in clinical use or coming online soon, says Suchi Saria, an AI researcher at the Johns Hopkins Whiting School of Engineering. One, made by Chicago-based Prenosis, won authorization from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration last April. Such AI help is important because sepsis can be hard to spot. Standard tests can’t ID the infectious microbe in most pneumonia cases. And there is no hard dividing line between sepsis and not sepsis. “Because the early signs are not as well understood, it’s very easy to not notice,” Saria says. “In this scenario, every hour matters.”
annotations.reason: Provides specific examples of AI applications in healthcare and their importance.

annotations.paragraph: Saria, who founded the company Bayesian Health, helped create an AI that sorts through electronic health records to detect early signs of sepsis. The AI, dubbed TREWS for Targeted Real-time Early Warning System, correctly flagged 82 percent of sepsis cases, Saria and colleagues reported in Nature Medicine in 2022.
annotations.reason: Details a specific AI system and its effectiveness in detecting sepsis.

annotations.paragraph: Sepsis patients whose doctors promptly responded to an alert from the AI were less likely to die and had shorter hospital stays than those whose doctors took over three hours to respond.
annotations.reason: Provides evidence of the AI's impact on patient outcomes.

annotations.paragraph: Many sepsis predictors comb electronic health data, says Tim Sweeney, cofounder and CEO of Inflammatix. Alternatively, his company developed a machine learning blood test, under review by the FDA, that measures 29 messenger RNAs (molecules that act as blueprints to make proteins) from white blood cells to tell whether an infection is bacterial or viral and to predict whether the patient will develop sepsis in the next week.
annotations.reason: Introduces another AI-based innovation and its potential application.

annotations.paragraph: Even if the test wins approval, the company will need to monitor its performance and update the test accordingly, Sweeney says. “It would be unethical not to have a mechanism to update the algorithm in some way with more data,” he says. Government approval may depend on having the right update plan. The FDA, Health Canada and the U.K. Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency have agreed on guidelines for updating medical devices that run on machine learning or more advanced AI.
annotations.reason: Discusses regulatory considerations and the importance of updating AI systems.

annotations.paragraph: AI is not a set-it-and-forget-it proposition, says Michael Matheny, a bioinformatician at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. Matheny and colleagues built an AI that evaluates hospitals on how well they prevent acute kidney injury — a sudden drop in the kidneys’ ability to filter waste products from the blood — after cardiac catheterization, a procedure often used to find and clear blocked arteries. If U.S. hospitals consistently used good preventive strategies, about half of the 140,000 yearly acute kidney injuries could be avoided, some studies suggest.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific examples of AI applications in health care and their potential impact.

annotations.paragraph: Matheny and colleagues trained the AI and made sure it worked in various settings. But over time, “we tried to use these models, and they kept breaking,” Matheny says. That’s because the data AI trains on aren’t always the same as the data it encounters in real life. Real-world data change, or “drift,” over time, so updates are needed.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses challenges in AI implementation, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: But Matheny’s team wanted to avoid unnecessary overhauls. The researchers used another AI to supervise the first one and set off alarms when results seemed fishy. The value of the supervisor became obvious when the COVID-19 pandemic hit, bringing the ultimate data drift.
annotations.reason: The paragraph explains a solution to a problem in AI application, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Before the pandemic, most cardiac catheterizations were elective outpatient procedures with lower risk of kidney injury. But then, in March 2020, “the data went crazy,” Matheny says. “All elective [catheterizations] were stopped for three or four months. The patients that were brought back into the cath lab after that were very different than your typical, average patient. And so the algorithm was broken.” But the supervisor flagged the issue, and the scientists corrected it.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a real-world example of AI adaptation during the pandemic, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: “If we’d done a fixed strategy, we would have had a period of time where the model was just flat broken,” Matheny says.
annotations.reason: The quote emphasizes the importance of adaptable AI strategies, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Hospitals that used the AI maintained lower than expected rates of kidney injury. But those same hospitals stopped using the system after the study. That’s an indication that AI developers need to make sure their systems are useful and trustworthy and have a plan to keep them reliable, says Sharon Davis, an informatician and Matheny’s colleague at Vanderbilt. “You can make the most accurate model in the world, but if we don’t deliver it well, and it doesn’t provide actionable information to providers,” she says, “it’s not going to change anything.” — Tina Hesman Saey
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific examples and expert commentary on the challenges of implementing AI in health care.
